body: Tiny mistake: to https://codesandbox.io/s/react-hook-form-nested-usefieldarray-forked-9znnu?file=/src/App.js

@bluebill1049 Thanks for the quick reply but your forked sandbox doesn't seem to be any different. If I click Remove Item in the top list isDirty is still false and no dirty fields are tracked. If I click Remove Order I do see dirty fields and isDirty is then true.
I tested the sandbox in Chrome 86 and Firefox 82.
@bluebill1049 Thank you so much for taking another look. This fix helped my team hit a critical deadline. I've recommended this project for sponsorship.
Thanks, @rrharvey for the kind words. My pleasure to help too.

@bluebill1049 - thank you once again for you prompt support with this package. We seem to be having this issue with fieldArray, which is behaving differently in development and production builds.

FieldArray works perfectly in development.  Adding, removing, re-ordering items all work fine when running `yarn start`.  Dirty state is updated and correct values sent to the API.  

However, when built to production - the items are removed from the array BUT the form values are not updated, so it sends the previous values back to the API (therefore not removing them).  Adding items there is no issue - it just happens on remove.  

Any reason why this behaviour would be different in development / production builds?

Thanks again.

> @bluebill1049 - thank you once again for you prompt support with this package. We seem to be having this issue with fieldArray, which is behaving differently in development and production builds.
> 
> FieldArray works perfectly in development. Adding, removing, re-ordering items all work fine when running `yarn start`. Dirty state is updated and correct values sent to the API.
> 
> However, when built to production - the items are removed from the array BUT the form values are not updated, so it sends the previous values back to the API (therefore not removing them). Adding items there is no issue - it just happens on remove.
> 
> Any reason why this behaviour would be different in development / production builds?
> 
> Thanks again.

can you share a codesandbox with the issue and deploy the prod version to some provider? so we can reproduce the issue, last time someone had this issue was due to ignoring warning during dev build.

It’s difficult to get a Sandbox up because it’s all hooked up to an API with sensitive company data which I’m unable to share. 

I am getting development warnings, as follows. 

`name` prop should be in object shape: name="test[index].name" {name: “content.faq_block.data"

I have tried the object shape for the name, but still no luck.  What should I be naming the field to get rid of this error?

P.S - just tried to donate for your support on OpenCollective but it’s erroring on payment ‘userId must be unique’.  Will keep trying as we appreciate your time and support.

Matt

That's definitely wrong tho: `content.faq_block.data`

it should at least contain an index of your Field Array.

egL `content[0].faq_block.data`
Hi @bluebill1049 - Ok the issue was we were using Controller as a parent of the FieldArray which was causing strange behaviour.  Removing this solved the problem!
